--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Chad Bohannan" <chad@b...> wrote:
> hey ken, 
> can you post a ling to all of your papers at once? You have the 
habit of
> posting exactly the paper I need to read, right when I'm ready to 
read
> it, ( this embrionic paper is pretty big though... ) so mayber you 
could
> post a 
> newbie link to read all that...
> 
> Before I start digging into 39 pages of glory, what are people's 
ideas
> for phenotypic morphologies? I was feeling all inspired that this 
was
> the next big thing, and I go to send the group an e-mail about it, 
and
> instead I read five different posts getting into the philosophy of 
it
> all. I love it.
> 
> Looking at the 'standard' genotype, there is two sets of numbers, 
one
> for the activation of the neurons, with one for each neuron, then a
> second list of numbers, with the weights, sources, and 
destinations of
> the links.
> 
> I am playing around with an additional history integration 
paramter,
> that effects the neurons, but the idea is the same. We are 
inheriting
> the graph structure idea from computer science classes with nodes 
and
> edges, and making brains out of them.
> 
> Now we want to evolve the structure by having part of our genome
> describe the expression of the genome into a phenotype. Ideas that 
come
> to mind are to embed our current idea of genotype into a larger 
genotype
> idea. In this super genome, a "gene" referes to what we have been
> calling a 'network.' This network evolves using the same NEAT 
we've been
> playing with. In the super NEAT genome, each network is treated in 
the
> same way as neuron is treated. Some changes in the super NEAT might
> include mutating the number of inputs and outputs a network gene 
has (
> slowly enough for the network to work with the new topology ).
> This approach doesn't seem to me to be the best way to encorage 
profound
> symetries that drasticly reduce search space, but it still might 
work,
> and be a start.
> 
> I just felt like I had to get that out there before I started 
reading
> that paper. 39 pages. Wow. These things don't read like pulp 
fiction.
> 
> chad
> 
> <-----Original Message-----> 
> >From: t_bommel
> >Sent: 6/16/2004 2:27:32 PM
> >To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> >Subject: Re: [neat] input
> >
> >hey guys,
> >
> >i was wondering if anyone could give me advice on how/what to 
input 
> >into my neural network (in progress). i'm a real newbie at this 
stuff 
> >so i still got alot to learn.
> >
> >i have rabbits and wolves im trying to figure how i should feed 
them 
> >information. should i feed them a 2 array of thier local 
environment 
> >and if so, how does doing that differ feeding it 1d arrays? 
> >
> >like i said, i'm a newb so any advice or referrals to other sites 
> >would be greatly appreciate. thanks
> >
